column2: Copying out the _Credo_ on a small sheet of parchment, he placed it over his heart, and his only answer to the fearful doubts that harassed him was to lay his hand upon it as he made his act of Faith. To prevent himself from dwelling on such thoughts, he devoted himself more than ever to works of charity, spending himself in the service of the sick and poor and comforting others when he himself was often in greater need of comfort.

column2: One day when the temptation was almost more than he could bear and he felt himself on the point of yielding, he made a vow to consecrate himself to Jesus Christ in the person of His poor.
column3: One day when the temptation was almost more than he could bear and he felt himself on the point of yielding, he made a vow to consecrate himself to Jesus Christ in the person of His poor.

column2: As he made the promise the temptation vanished, and forever.

column2: His faith henceforward was a faith that had been tried and had conquered; strong and firm as such a faith must be, it held him ready for all that God might send.

column2: Chapter 3 A GREAT HOUSEHOLD
column3: Chapter three A GREAT HOUSEHOLD

column2: VINCENT remained two years in the house of Father de Berulle, in the hope of obtaining permanent work.
column3: VINCENT remained two years in the house of Father de Berulle, in the hope of obtaining permanent work.

column2: The administration of a poor country parish was, he maintained, the only thing he was fit for, but de Berulle thought otherwise.
column3: The administration of a poor country parish was, he maintained, the only thing he was fit for, but de Berulle thought otherwise.

column2: This humble priest, he predicted one day to a friend, "will render great service to the Church and will work much for God's glory."
column3: This humble priest, he predicted one day to a friend, "will render great service to the Church and will work much for God's glory."

column2: St. Francis de Sales, who made Vincent's acquaintance while he was with de Berulle, was of the same opinion.
column3: saint Francis de Sales, who made Vincent's acquaintance while he was with de Berulle, was of the same opinion.

column2: He will be the holiest priest of his time, he said one day as he watched him.
column3: He will be the holiest priest of his time, he said one day as he watched him.

column3: As for Vincent, he was completely won by the gentle serenity of saint Francis and took him as model in his relations with others.

column2: I am by nature a country clod, he would say in after years, "and if I had not met the Bishop of Geneva, I should have remained a bundle of thorns all my life."
column3: I am by nature a country clod, he would say in after years, "and if I had not met the Bishop of Geneva, I should have remained a bundle of thorns all my life."

column2: At last Vincent's desire seemed about to be fulfilled.
column3: At last Vincent's desire seemed about to be fulfilled.

column2: A friend of de Berulle's, cure of the country parish of Clichy, near Paris, announced his intention of entering the Oratory, and at de Berulle's request chose Vincent de Paul as his successor.
column3: A friend of de Berulle's, cure of the country parish of Clichy, near Paris, announced his intention of entering the Oratory, and at de Berulle's request chose Vincent de Paul as his successor.

column2: Here, amidst his beloved poor, Vincent was completely happy.
column3: Here, amidst his beloved poor, Vincent was completely happy.

column2: In him the sick and the infirm found a friend such as they had never dreamed of and any son of poor parents who showed a vocation for the priesthood was taken into the presbytery and taught by Vincent himself.
column3: In him the sick and the infirm found a friend such as they had never dreamed of and any son of poor parents who showed a vocation for the priesthood was taken into the presbytery and taught by Vincent himself.

column2: The parish church, which was in great disrepair, was rebuilt; old, standing quarrels were made up; men who had not been to the Sacraments for years came back to God.
column3: The parish church, which was in great disrepair, was rebuilt; old, standing quarrels were made up; men who had not been to the Sacraments for years came back to God.

column2: Such was the influence of the Cure of Clichy that priests from the neighboring parishes came to learn the secret of his success and to ask his advice.
column3: Such was the influence of the Cure of Clichy that priests from the neighboring parishes came to learn the secret of his success and to ask his advice.

column2: Vincent was looking forward to a life spent in earnest work among his people when a summons from Father de Berulle recalled him suddenly to Paris.
column3: Vincent was looking forward to a life spent in earnest work among his people when a summons from Father de Berulle recalled him suddenly to Paris.

column2: Nothing less than the resignation of his beloved Clichy was now asked of him by this friend to whom he owed so much.
column3: Nothing less than the resignation of his beloved Clichy was now asked of him by this friend to whom he owed so much.

column2: One of the greatest noblemen of France, Messire de Gondi, Count of Joigny and General of the King's Galleys, was in need of a tutor for his children and had commissioned Father de Berulle to find him what he wanted.
column3: One of the greatest noblemen of France, Messire de Gondi, Count of Joigny and General of the King's Galleys, was in need of a tutor for his children and had commissioned Father de Berulle to find him what he wanted.

column2: De Berulle decided at once that Vincent de Paul was the man for the position and that, as he was evidently destined to do great work for God, it would be to his advantage to have powerful and influential friends.
column3: De Berulle decided at once that Vincent de Paul was the man for the position and that, as he was evidently destined to do great work for God, it would be to his advantage to have powerful and influential friends.

column2: Although the prospect of such a post filled the humble parish priest with consternation, he owed too much to de Berulle to refuse.
column3: Although the prospect of such a post filled the humble parish priest with consternation, he owed too much to de Berulle to refuse.

column2: Setting out from Clichy with his worldly goods on a hand-barrow, he arrived at the Oratory, from whence he was to proceed to his new abode.
column3: Setting out from Clichy with his worldly goods on a hand barrow, he arrived at the Oratory, from whence he was to proceed to his new abode.

column2: The house of Messire de Gondi was one of the most magnificent in Paris.
column3: The house of Messire de Gondi was one of the most magnificent in Paris.

column2: The Count, one of the bravest and handsomest men of his day, was in high favor at Court; while his wife, at a time when the lives of most of the great ladies of the Court were anything but edifying, was remarkable for her fervor and piety.
column3: The Count, one of the bravest and handsomest men of his day, was in high favor at Court; while his wife, at a time when the lives of most of the great ladies of the Court were anything but edifying, was remarkable for her fervor and piety.

column2: The de Gondi children, unfortunately, did not take after their parents, and the two boys whose education Vincent was to undertake and whose character he was to form were described by their aunt as "regular little demons." The youngest of the family, the famous, or rather infamous, Cardinal de Retz, was not yet born, but Vincent's hands were sufficiently full without him.

column2: The violent temper and obstinacy of his charges were a great trial to Vincent, who used to say in later life that they had taught him, cross-grained as he was by nature, how to be gentle and patient.

column2: The position of a man of low birth as tutor in that princely household was not without its difficulties.
column3: The position of a man of low birth as tutor in that princely household was not without its difficulties.

column2: Vincent was a dependent; but there was a quiet dignity about him which forbade liberties.

column3: With the servants, and there were many of every grade, he was always cordial and polite, losing no chance of winning their confidence, that he might influence them for good.

column3: His duties over, he would retire to his own room, refusing, unless especially sent for, to mix with the great people who frequented the house.

column2: It was the age of dueling, and hundreds of lives were lost in this barbarous practice.
column3: It was the age of dueling, and hundreds of lives were lost in this barbarous practice.

column2: De Gondi was a famous swordsman, and although the life he led was a great deal better than that of the majority of his contemporaries, the possibility of refusing to fight when challenged, or of refraining from challenging another when his honor was at stake, had never occurred to him.
column3: De Gondi was a famous swordsman, and although the life he led was a great deal better than that of the majority of his contemporaries, the possibility of refusing to fight when challenged, or of refraining from challenging another when his honor was at stake, had never occurred to him.

column2: Vincent had been some time at the de Gondis' when it came to his ears that the Count intended to fight a duel on a certain day, and he resolved, if possible, to prevent it.
column3: Vincent had been some time at the de Gondis' when it came to his ears that the Count intended to fight a duel on a certain day, and he resolved, if possible, to prevent it.

column2: Vincent waited till everyone had gone out, and then approached him softly.
column3: Vincent waited till everyone had gone out, and then approached him softly.

column2: Monsieur, he said, "I know that you intend to fight a duel; and I tell you, as a message from my Saviour, before whom you kneel, that if you do not renounce this intention His judgment will fall on you and yours." The Count, after a moment's silence, promised to give up his project, and faithfully kept his word.

column2: The man was conscious, and Vincent--moved, no doubt, by the direct inspiration of God--urged him to make a General Confession.

column2: Can you do nothing to help them?"
